Data Overview

Home | Data Overview | Multi-Dimensional Analysis | Models | Conclusion


This data is survey data collected at Utah Valley University in the Spring and Fall 2020 semesters. The survey explores different aspects of science motivation, with a goal of understanding what things may have an effect on a student’s science motivation. The questions were adapted from other surveys found in the literature review conducted. Different aspects of demographics were measured, as well. These are the different aspects of science motivation that we explored:

Question Types


Science Identity

Questions regarding “Science Identity” included:

  • “I see myself as a biology person”
  • “I see myself as a science person”
  • “I see myself as a scientist”
  • “Other people (friends/family) see me as a science person”
  • “My science instructors see me as a science person”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Career Motivation

Questions regarding “Career Motivation” included:

  • “Learning science will help me get a good job”
  • “Understanding science will benefit me in my career”
  • “Knowing science will give me a career advantage”
  • “I will use science problem-solving skills in my career”
  • “My career will involve science”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Intrinsic Motivation

Questions regarding “Intrinsic Motivation” included:

  • “Learning science is interesting”
  • “I am curious about discoveries in science”
  • “The science I learn is relevant to my life”
  • “Learning science makes my life more meaningful”
  • “I enjoy learning science”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Self-Determination

Questions regarding “Self-Determination” included:

  • “I study hard to learn science”
  • “I prepare well for science tests and labs”
  • “I put enough effort into learning science”
  • “I spend a lot of time learning science”
  • “I use strategies to learn science well”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Self-Efficacy

Questions regarding “Self-Efficacy” included:

  • “I am confident I will do well on science labs and projects”
  • “I believe I can earn a grade of ‘A’ in science”
  • “I am confident I will do well on science tests”
  • “I believe I can master science knowledge and skills”
  • “I am sure I can understand science”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Grade Motivation

Questions regarding “Grade Motivation” included:

  • “Scoring high on science tests and labs matters to me”
  • “It is important that I get an ‘A’ in science”
  • “I think about the grade I will get in science”
  • “Getting a good science grade is important to me”
  • “I like to do better than other students on science tests”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Science Competency

Questions regarding “Science Competency” included:

  • “I am good at solving complicated scientific problems”
  • “I read websites, articles, or books about scientific issues”
  • “I work on a project involving scientific concepts”
  • “I think about how my life is affected by science”

Questions were measured on a 5 point scale, from “Strongly Disagree” to “Strongly Agree”.

Personal Community Orientation

Questions regarding “Personal Community Orientation” included:

  • “To what extent is serving your community important to you?”
  • “To what extent is working with people important to you?”
  • “To what extent is helping others important to you?”
  • “To what extent is connecting with others important to you?”

These questions were given choices from “Not important at all” to “Extremely important” as answer choices.

Science Community Orientation

Questions regarding “Science Community Orientation” included:

  • “To what extent is serving your community important to scientific work?”
  • “To what extent is working with people important to scientific work?”
  • “To what extent is helping others important to scientific work?”
  • “To what extent is connecting with others important to scientific work?”

These questions were given choices from “Not important at all” to “Extremely important” as answer choices.

Purpose of the Experiment

In my experiences in life, I have had many medical experiences that have affected who I am today. This has caused me to have a desire my whole life to enter the medical field. As I got in college, I jumped right into the sciences because “that is what you have to do” to get into medical school. Along the way in my undergraduate experience, I found that I have a love for science that I didn’t realize. I now want to be a medical doctor and a scientist. I decided I wanted to learn whether or not this was a normal course for science motivation or if I was just a weirdo. Through background literature review, we found that there are many studies exploring having medical conditions leading to a desire to enter the medical field, but there has been no study regarding medical experiences leading to science motivation. Therefore, we are studying it. Our hypothesis is that there are other people like me, that medical conditions do lead to a higher science motivation. Therefore, we essentially took a typical science motivation questionnaire that our lab group has used in the past and threw on a couple of questions on regarding medical experiences. Boring? Maybe a little bit, but we are hoping that this research will help influence doctors, teachers, parents, or anyone dealing with potential STEM students to help encourage those students into the STEM fields.
